sections.heading: CsPbBr3 Quantum Dots 2.0: Benzenesulfonic Acid Equivalent Ligand Awakens Complete Purification
Dandan Yang, Xiaoming Li,* Wenhan Zhou, Shengli Zhang, Cuifang Meng, Ye Wu,
Yue Wang, and Haibo Zeng*

bonds.[18,19] The formation of hydrogen bonds reduces the coulombic interactions between lead and bromide ions, and then ammonium ligands will fall off from the QD surface along with bromide ions (Scheme 1a left).[20] On the other hand, the deprotonated ammonium ligands cannot interact with the CsPbBr3 QDs.
Therefore, the use of a single ligand without amine groups and reversible processes could overcome the purification stability problem, as shown recently by Yassitepe et al, who developed an aminefree method using only oleic acid (OA) as ligands.[21] The resulting CsPbBr3 QDs could be washed several times without size increase or emission shift (Scheme 1a middle); however, the QY of these QDs was relatively low and the long-term stability was poor. The low QY results from the presence of enormous surface bromide
vacancies (VBr), since VBr exhibited obvious negative exciton trapping effect (Scheme 1b middle).[22] The groups of both Xia and Alivisatos recently confirmed the effect of VBr in their very recent works and near 100% QY can be achieved swimmingly by compensating Br ions with any bromides during or after synthesis (Scheme 1b left).[23,24] Hence, it seems contradictory that considering the QY, surface VBr should be avoided, while on account of good stability, ammonium which interacts with Br atoms should be excluded. To reduce the VBr density and reversible protonation, Kovalenko et al. introduced several kinds of zwitterionic ligands.[15,25] CsPbBr3 QDs maintained high QY values of ≈80% and exhibited good purification stability. However, the preparation procedures were complicated, and even required precursor synthesis. Tan et al. reported the preparation of highly luminescent and stable CsPbBr3 QDs prepared with addition of octylphosphonic acid (OPA).[26] However, in addition to OPA, the preparation also required the introduction of OA and trioctylphosphine oxide (TOPO), complicating the mechanism because TOPO and OA can also passivate and efficiently stabilize the CsPbBr3 surface.[27,28] Additionally, OPA is insoluble in octadecene and is unable to dissolve PbBr2 without TOPO.[29]
In this work, we propose a concept of equivalent ligand, hypothesizing that if a ligand can play a role similar to Br ions to a certain extent and form strong interaction with lead ions (surfactant), then the problems of VBr and weak interaction can be solved simultaneously. The simplest source of Br ions is HBr, and
The stability and optoelectronic device performance of perovskite quantum dots (Pe-QDs) are severely limited by present ligand strategies since these ligands exhibit a highly dynamic binding state, resulting in serious complications in QD purification and storage. Here, a “Br-equivalent” ligand strategy is developed in which the proposed strong ionic sulfonate heads, for example, benzenesulfonic acid, can firmly bind to the exposed Pb ions to form a steady binding state, and can also effectively eliminate the exciton trapping probability due to bromide vacancies. From these two aspects, the sulfonate heads play a similar role as natural Br ions in a perfect perovskite lattice. Using this approach, high photoluminescence quantum yield (PL QY) > 90% is facilely achieved without the need for amine-related ligands. Furthermore, the prepared PL QYs are well maintained after eight purification cycles, more than five months of storage, and high-flux photo-irradiation. This is the first report of high and versatile stabilities of Pe-QD, which should enable their improved application in lighting, displays, and biologic imaging.

sections.heading: Perovskite Quantum Dots
sections.text:
Inorganic cesium lead halide (CsPbX3, X = Cl, Br, I) perovskite quantum dots (QDs) have attracted great attention in recent years due to their high photoluminescence quantum yield (PL QY) and high color purity.[1–8] Their high defect tolerance provides bright PL that is free from passivation shells.[9,10] However, these QDs still suffer from severe purification problems, which can grow into large particles and lose their high PL QY after several purification cycles.[11,12] These phenomena are also frequently observed during storage, even with inert gas protection. These obstacles greatly hinder the performance and stability enhancement of devices.[13,14] The instability results from the strong electronegativity of nitrogen atoms and reversible protonated and deprotonated processes.[12,15–17] On one hand, CsPbBr3 QDs are terminated with bromide ions and the ammonium interacts with bromide atoms through hydrogen
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900767
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (2 of 8)
considering the strong acidity of HBr, long chain benzenesulfonic acids with strong acidity might meet the above two requirements due to the strong electron withdrawing ability of benzenesulfonic groups. The elimination of exciton traps and strong ligand binding state were verified with both theoretical and experimental results (Scheme 1a,b, right). Finally, CsPbBr3 QDs prepared with only dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) exhibited QY larger than 90%, and this value was maintained even after eight purification cycles and more than five months of storage.
The electronic structure origin of the VBr-mediated exciton trapping via density function theory is shown in Figure 1a. We can see that the band edges of CsPbBr3 consist of Pb 6p and Br 4p orbits.[2] The existence of surface VBr reduces the energy of related Pb 6p states and then obvious defect energy levels emerge within the band gap. From the electron localization function results we can see that VBr leads to obvious deformation of the electron cloud around Pb atoms compared to the what happens in defect-free parts (Figure 1b). The localization of wave function around lead atoms is reduced, which delocalizes nearly outside and usually contributes to nonradiative recombination, especially for QDs. Though it is reported that the defect energy level of VBr is predicted to be shallow, the presence of VBr can indeed influence the QY greatly, suggesting the gap between the ideal simulation and practical phenomenon needs more investigation.[9,10,30] To raise the energy of Pb 6p states to eliminate the defect energy levels, ligands with anionic heads with similar electronic features to those of Br− ions should be favorable.
After coordinating with sulfonate ions, it is obvious that the Pb 6p energy level was raised and the defect states disappeared (Figure 1c). The final density of states (DOS) after the coordination of sulfonate ions almost was the same as that of defect-free CsPbBr3, indicating the efficient passivation effect of sulfonate ions on QDs (Figure 1c, the dot-line curve). After passivation, the delocalization of the electron cloud was excluded successfully
(Figure 1d). The binding energy of CH3NH3+-Br with lead atoms was calculated as 1.47 eV, and the value between the sulfonate groups and lead atoms was 1.64 eV. Therefore, according to the simulation results, the sulfonate groups not only alleviated the defect of the electronic structure, but also interacted vigorously with lead ions. This suggested that CsPbBr3 QDs passivated by DBSA could exhibit high QY and robust stability.
Fortunately, the above-proposed strategy can be tested experimentally. To do this, the DBSA-passivated CsPbBr3 QDs can be facilely synthesized through a modified hot-injection method. Briefly, cesium carbonate, lead acetate, and DBSA are added simultaneously into a vessel and then tetraoctylammonium bromide (TOAB) is applied as the halide precursor. A transparent solution can form before injection, implying the complete formation of cesium and lead sulfonates. Large steric hindrance due to the four long alkyl chains in TOAB makes it undetectable on the surface of CsPbBr3 QDs (Figure S1, Supporting Information).[31] This demonstrates that only DBSA anchors on the QD surface as a passivation and stabilization agent.
The expected strong interaction between DBSA and QDs was demonstrated systemically, as shown in Figure 2. Obvious chemical shift and broadening of benzene ring-related hydrogen peaks are obvious in the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra (Figure 2a), indicating the strong binding state of DBSA on QD surface. Importantly, the octadecene solvent is not detected on the surface.[13] The existence of sulfonate groups and the binding motif of PbO (Figure 2b inset) are evidenced by S 2p and O 1s X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) results and typical infrared vibration modes of sulfonate groups (Figures S2 and S3, Supporting Information). Diffusion ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) measurement was next carried out to estimate the interaction strength between the ligands and QDs (Figure 2b). OA-capped QDs were not studied here due to their low QY. Generally, the diffusion coefficient of a molecule

Scheme 1. Comparison of different ligand strategies. a) Binding motif on CsPbBr3 QD surface and interaction strength of OAm OA, and DBSA ligands. b) The effect of different ligands on exciton recombination dynamics. The proposed “Br-equivalent” ligand strategy is shown in the two right images, where the strong ionic sulfonate heads firmly bind to the exposed Pb ions to form a steady ligand binding state, effectively eliminating bromide vacancyrelated exciton trapping behavior.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (3 of 8)
in solution can be estimated via the Stokes–Einstein equation of D = kBT/f, where D is the diffusion coefficient, kB is the Boltzmann constant, T is the absolute temperature, and f is the friction coefficient. For the cubic perovskite QDs, the expression of f should be modified as f = 6πηC and C = 0.66d, where d is the size of the QDs.[15,32,33] If the ligands completely bind to the surface of QDs without falling off, the measured D of the organic content should be similar to that of the total object, including the QDs and the ligand shell. The measured D1 of DBSA in the presence of QDs was 121 µm2 s−1, a value that was much smaller than that for oleylamine (OAm)-capped QDs (166 µm2 s−1), indicating stronger interaction between ligands and the QD surface (Figure 2b).[15] Considering an average size of ≈9.5 nm, the calculated D2 is ≈63.3 µm2 s−1, according to above equation. The difference between D1 and D2 implies that these ligands will also exhibit a free state to some extent, although this probability is much smaller than that for OAm-capped QDs (Figure 2b). Hence, the DBSA groups bind to the QD surface tightly and will protect during purification, storage, and irradiation.
To further verify the strong interaction between DBSA and QDs, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were conducted for QDs after different washing cycles (Figure 2c,d). The CH2 vibration signals were
tracked as indicators of the organic ligand content on QD surface due to their strong and narrow features (Figure S4, Supporting Information).[34] Increased purification times resulted in decreased vibration intensity for both samples, indicating the loss of ligands during purification. A large decrease was observed for the first two cycles, which can be attributed to the exclusion of ODE. The decrease rate for OAm-QDs was much faster than that for the DBSA-QDs, implying a stronger interaction between DBSA and CsPbBr3 QDs. The TG results were highly consistent with the FTIR measurements that the decrease rate of organic ligand content decrease was much faster for OAm-QDs than that of DBSA-QDs (Figure 2d). The higher weight percentage for DBSA-QDs is due to the larger molecular weight of DBSA. The exact content of organic matter for DBSA-QDs is lower than that of OAm-QDs (Figure S5, Supporting Information), suggesting excellent purity of DBSA-QDs, which would enable potential applications as high-performance LEDs.
Since the defect states can be efficiently passivated according to the theoretical calculation and because the ligands bind to QDs tightly, the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs are expected to show high efficiency and good stability and be free from purification problems. Figure 3a shows DBSA-QD colloidal solutions subjected to different washing cycles under daylight and UV light.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900767
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (4 of 8)
There was no obvious difference between these eight samples in terms of efficiency, emission wavelength, or dispersity, which is totally different from the QDs prepared by the classical method with OA and OAm.[11] In that system, the emission wavelength red-shifted gradually (Figure S6, Supporting Information) with an obvious increase of particle size after washing. In contrast, for the CsPbBr3 QDs here, the emission wavelength and absorption peaks remained steady with little shift (Figure 3b).
In addition to the robust purification endurance, the QDs maintained their high PL QY (>90%) without obvious deterioration (Figure 3c). In contrast, the QDs prepared with either OAm or OA exhibited a severe decrease in the QY values with increased washing time. The difference can be attributed to the strong interaction between DBSA and lead ions, as shown by the DOSY results. During purification, the highly dynamic OA and OAm could escape from the surface of QDs, resulting in aggregation and an imperfect passivation effect (Figure S7, Supporting Information).[15] Herein, the sulfonate group chelates tightly to the exposed surface lead ions. The bound state is maintained throughout the whole purification processes, so the QDs are passivated efficiently, from beginning to end. The good passivation effect is also confirmed by the PL decay results, as shown in Figure 3d. The three curves show very similar decay
behavior, with fitted lifetimes of 3.26, 3.79, and 3.63 ns, respectively (Table S1, Supporting Information). The faster radiative rate and high QY values of all the three samples again manifest the strong interaction between sulfonate groups and lead ions and good passivation effect on CsPbBr3 QDs.
Usually, after purification, the size of perovskite QDs increase and the crystallinity improves (Figure S8, Supporting Information). However, the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy images (Figure S9, Supporting Information) manifest a stable particle size, around 8 nm, even after five washes (Figure 3e), a finding that agrees well with the observed stable emission peak. All particles exhibit obvious lattice fringe, indicating the good crystallinity of these QDs. The QDs maintained their crystallinity and similar X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were observed as shown in Figure 3f. The full width at half maximum values of all the curves were similar for the different QDs. These results are consistent with the unchanged particle size observed in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. The most significant influence of purification is the modulation of surface states; for the perovskite QDs, the effect is usually negative. Figure 3g shows the XPS results of samples washed for different times. One can see there is no obvious binding energy shift for the Pb 4f
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900767
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (5 of 8)
curves, implying stable surface states of the CsPbBr3 QDs. Therefore, the purification process only eliminates the excessive solvent and ligands, and the anchored ligands remain firmly bound at the surface. As a result, no new defects form and the QDs maintain their excellent QY, consistent with the PL decay results.
In addition to the purification problem, storage stability is also an important issue that must be addressed for practical applications. On one hand, the highly dynamic ligand binding of perovskite QDs makes these particles unstable. These QDs aggregate together and grow into large crystals with single crystallinity, even at a low colloidal concentration, leading to redshifted emission and decreased efficiency (Figure S10, Supporting Information). However, during storage, the large change of temperature and destruction from moisture usually aggravate the above disadvantages. Additionally, these behaviors are irreversible. Both OA- and OAm-capped CsPbBr3 QDs underwent this kind of deterioration. As shown in Figure 4a
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900767
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (6 of 8)
and Figure S11, Supporting Information, the colloidal solution of these two samples changed from clear and transparent to cloudy due to the formation of large particles. The emission peaks increased from 517 and 511 nm to 520 and 513.5 nm, respectively (Figure S12, Supporting Information). Additionally, after five months, the QY of these two samples decreased greatly, to only 55% and 26% of their initial values (Figure 4b; Figure S13, Supporting Information). The decrease of QY was also revealed by the images under UV lamp, and OA-capped QDs exhibited better stability than OAm-capped QDs.
In contrast to these disappointing findings, DBSA-capped QDs exhibited robust storage stability. Though the room temperature varied from 30 to −6 °C and the moisture changed from 20% to 80%, the colloidal solution remained clear and transparent without any protection, as shown in Figure 4a. Strong green emission comparable to the initial performance under UV light was observed, and this was also confirmed by PL QY measurement (Figure 4b). After five months, the emission wavelength of DBSA-capped QDs remained stable, and the PL curves were nearly the same (Figure S12, Supporting Information).
It has been frequently reported that QD size will increase along with the redshift of emission peak wavelength and deterioration of QY under light illumination.[35] The OAm-QDs exhibited similar behavior under ultrahigh laser light flux (405 nm, 820 mW cm−2, Figure 5a; Figure S14, Supporting
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900767
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900767 (7 of 8)
Information). The emission wavelength redshifted from 515.4 to 521 nm after illumination of 400 min, and only 58% of the initial QY was maintained. However, the DBSA-QDs showed stable peak wavelength, even under such a high light intensity (Figure 5b). This is totally different from previous results and indicates stable QD size during treatment. Additionally, 68% of the initial QY was achieved, higher than that of OAm-QDs.
To further confirm the enhanced stability of DBSA-QDs, the thermal stability of thin films was evaluated. The DBSAQD film maintained the emission peak wavelength and exhibited high PL intensity endurance (89%) after treatment at 60 °C for 150 h (Figure 5c,d). In contrast, the emission wavelength of OAm-QDs changed from 515.4 to 523.4 nm, and only 23% of the initial PL intensity was maintained. These results again manifest the strong binding effect of the sulfonate groups on the QD surface and suggest potential applications in future optoelectronic devices. To date, many surface passivation strategies have been proposed to simultaneously improve the QY and stability. One strategy is to directly passivate QDs during synthesis with different ligand system (Table S2, Supporting Information). Another strategy is the post-treatment of QDs with various agents (Table S3, Supporting Information). Despite attempts to apply these strategies, there are few reports of increased stability of perovskite QDs with maintenance of high PL QY. The complete purification of perovskite QDs still remains challenging. DBSA-QDs not only possess high QY, but also can be purified completely and exhibit good resistance against light irradiation and heat treatment, indicating their potential applications in optoelectronic devices.
In conclusion, in this work, we developed a new ligand strategy and overcame the purification and storage problems successfully. The elimination of nonradiative recombination is fulfilled by an equivalent ligand by raising the orbit energy of exposed Pb atoms. Both the theoretical and experimental results are consistent with this model. The equivalent ligands not only solve the luminescence efficiency issue due to VBr, but also contribute to a strong interaction between ligands and the QD surface, as shown by the relatively low diffusion coefficient and good stability. CsPbBr3 QDs capped by the equivalent ligand show QY above 90%, stable emission peaks, good long-term storage stability, and robust high-energy irradiation stability, even after five washes. This work will not only promote the investigation of perovskite QDs in optoelectronic devices, but also facilitate efforts to modify single particle core-shell structures with multiple functions and applications.

sections.heading: Experimental Section
sections.text:
Synthesis of 1,4-DBSA-CsPbBr3 QDs: Cs2CO3 (0.0593 g, 0.182 mmoL), Pb(OAc)2 (0.206 g, 0.54 mmoL), ODE (10 mL), and dodecyl benzene sulfonic acid (1.2045 g, 3.689 mmoL) were loaded into a 100 mL threeneck flask and the mixture was degassed for half an hour at 120 °C under Ar flow. The transparent solution was maintained under 120 °C for another 30 min, and then pre-dissolved toluene solution of TOAB (748 mg, 1.37 mmol, 2 mL) was swiftly injected into the above precursor solution. After 5 s, the reaction mixture was cooled down using a water bath.
Synthesis of OAm-CsPbBr3 QDs: OAm-QDs were synthesized as described previously. Briefly, PbBr2 (0.54 mmoL, 0.2 g), ODE (15 mL), OA (1.5 mL), and OAm (1.5 mL) were loaded into a 100 mL three-neck flask and degassed for half an hour at 120 °C under Ar flow. After complete dissolution of PbBr2 salt, the temperature was increased to 160 °C and then maintained for another 30 min under Ar atmosphere. The preheated Cs-oleate solution was swiftly injected into the transparent precursor solution. After 5 s, the reaction mixture was cooled down using a water bath.
Synthesis of OA-CsPbBr3 QDs: Cs2CO3 (0.0593 g, 0.182 mmoL), Pb(OAc)2 (0.206 g, 0.54 mmoL), ODE (15 mL), and OA (1.5 mL) were loaded into a 100 mL three-neck flask and degassed for half an hour at 120 °C under Ar flow. The temperature was lowered to 85 °C and then maintained for 30 min under Ar atmosphere. After the complete dissolution of inorganic salts, the pre-dissolved toluene solution of TOAB (748 mg, 1.023 mmol, 2 mL, 85 °C) was swiftly injected into the transparent precursor solution. Then, 5 s later, the mixture was cooled using a water bath.
Purification of the CsPbBr3 QDs: Ethyl acetate was added into the crude solution at a volume ratio of 1:3 and the mixture was centrifuged for 1 min at 9000 rpm. The precipitate was dispersed into 6 mL of toluene and then 18 mL of ethyl acetate was added. The crude solution was again centrifuged for 1 min at 9000 rpm. Then, the above purification steps were repeated several times. The final QDs were dispersed in 2 mL of toluene (hexane or octane) to obtain a clear solution.
Computational Details: The structural optimizations and electronic structure calculations are performed based on density functional theory as implemented in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) code.[36] Exchange correlation energies are considered by the generalized gradient approximation using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) function.[37] The wave functions are constructed using a projected augmented wave approach with a plane wave cutoff energy of 500 eV. The convergence threshold was set as 10−4 eV in energy and 10−3 eV Å−1 in force. The Brillouin zone integration is sampled using a set of 9 × 9 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-points.
Characterization: Powder X-ray diffraction data was recorded on Bruker D8 Advance using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.542 Å). UV–vis spectra were recorded in the range of 300–700 nm by using a UV spectrometer (Shimadzu UV-3600). The PL measurements were collected on a Varian Cary Eclipse instrument. TEM images were collected on a TECNAI G2 20 LaB6 instrument at 200 kV. XPS measurements were performed using an achromatic Al Kα source (1486.6 eV) and a double pass cylindrical mirror analyzer (PHI QUANTERA II). FTIR results were measured with a Tensor-27 spectrometer. The absolute PL QY of the solution of QDs was determined using a Quantaurus-QY absolute photoluminescence quantum yield spectrometer (C11347-11, Hamamatsu Photonics, Japan). The lifetimes of PL were detected by a homemade instrument with a 375 nm picosecond laser.
